header_summary:
Keyser Söze and others have introduced two Bitcoin Improvement Proposals aimed at enhancing wallet interoperability and security, with a focus on a standardized format for wallet data serialization and a secure container for encrypted wallet data. These proposals, still in the early stages, seek community feedback to refine their approach for better wallet backups and transfers within the Bitcoin ecosystem. The drafts can be reviewed [here for the Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/7109a7f0455897b1930f851bde6337e3) and [here for the Standard Wallet Encryption Envelope](https://gist.github.com/KeysSoze/866d009ccd082edf6802df240154b20d).

The Bitcoin Core development team has released the candidate for version v30.0rc1, a significant update that is now available for testing, with binaries and source code accessible through [Bitcoin Core's official page](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc1/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v30.0rc1) respectively. This release candidate, accompanied by a draft of preliminary release notes and a testing guide, marks a crucial phase before the official launch of version 30.0, with feedback solicited from the development community.

A workshop facilitated by Michael Zaikin on the ctv-csfs-activation IRC channel has brought Bitcoin developers together to discuss the CHECKSIGFROMSTACK Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP), exploring its use cases and engaging in transaction creation. With an upcoming session scheduled to further discuss the creation of different types of pools using CTV and CSFS, this initiative underlines the community's commitment to advancing Bitcoin development through collaborative knowledge sharing. The workshop's logs are available [here](https://ctv-csfs-workshops.github.io/bip348/logs).

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Standard Encrypted Wallet Payload + Standard Encryption Envelope formats
recent_posts.summary:
- Two proposed Bitcoin Improvement Proposals aim to enhance wallet interoperability and security.
- The first proposal introduces a format for wallet data serialization, focusing on encryption and extensibility.
- The second proposal focuses on creating a secure container for encrypted wallet data, requiring community feedback.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 release candidate is now available.
- Binaries and source code are accessible through official pages and GitHub.
- Critical testing before final release, feedback can be submitted via GitHub issue tracker.

recent_posts.title: IRC logs: BIP 348 Workshop
recent_posts.summary:
- The workshop led by Michael Zaikin on the ctv-csfs-activation IRC channel focused on BIP.

recent_posts.title: MultiChannel and MultiPTLC: Towards A Global High-Availability CP Database For Bitcoin Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- PTLCs face risks from quantum computing, needing evaluation for future security.
- The CAP theorem interests those in database architecture, requiring careful terminology.
- Suggesting "global CP database" may evoke sensitive topics, advising alternative nomenclature.

recent_posts.title: Stealth addresses using nostr
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal introduces a cryptographic method for secure key exchanges using NIP-17.
- It details an equation involving hash functions and elliptic curve cryptography for security.
- The email expresses interest in the theoretical underpinnings rather than practical applications.

recent_posts.title: Open letter to core devs (reflections/questions from the op_return saga and proposal to establish a well-organized channel/link between devs and users)
recent_posts.summary:
- Recent Bitcoin changes aimed to address counterproductive limitations and workarounds in data embedding.
- Mismatches in node and miner policies disrupt Bitcoin network efficiency and block propagation.
- Disparities in Bitcoin node types and representations raise concerns about network decentralization.

active_posts.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal targets enhancing Bitcoin's defense against quantum threats through post-quantum cryptography.
- It outlines a phased adoption of new cryptographic standards, including a new address type, P2QRH.
- The initiative stresses the urgency of quantum-resistant measures to protect Bitcoin's value and integrity.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] No burn, Quantum Migration Proposal, Quantum Secure Asset Verification & Escrow (QSAVE)
active_posts.summary:
- James Tagg proposes QSAVE to protect Bitcoins from quantum threats via a wealth fund model.
- QSAVE aims to secure vulnerable Bitcoins while funding protocol support and public welfare.
- The initiative offers a safeguard against quantum decryption, focusing on ownership preservation and societal benefit.

active_posts.title: BIP Booby Trapped Wallets - Covenant-Only Taproot Outputs
active_posts.summary:
- Matias Monteagudo proposes enhancing Bitcoin wallet security with covenant-only Taproot outputs.
- The proposal targets institutional holders, introducing transaction restrictions for improved security.
- It outlines technical specifications, deployment strategies, and addresses security, preserving privacy and efficiency.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners have shifted policies, adopting full RBF and enhanced spam filters.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation times, improving network efficiency.
- Alternative solutions like weak blocks and template sharing aim to enhance network robustness.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal aims to relax Bitcoin Core's `OP_RETURN` output limits, stirring community debate.
- Critics argue it may misuse Bitcoin for data storage, missing the proposal's intent to improve network efficiency.
- The discussion raises broader concerns about Bitcoin's governance and the need for informed, technical debates on its future.

active_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
active_posts.summary:
- A study reveals vulnerabilities in the Bitcoin network, allowing eclipse attacks via BGP hijacking.
- Attackers can control Bitcoin traffic by manipulating BGP routes, enabling potential abuses like double spending.
- Proposed mitigations include periodic peer rotation and leveraging RPKI-protected connections for enhanced security.

today_in_history_posts.title: Requesting BIP assignment; Flexible Transactions.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A Bitcoin Improvement Proposal for "Flexible Transactions" seeks to enhance Bitcoin's core transactions.
- The proposal introduces Compact Message Format for future-proof feature additions and malleability fixes.
- It specifies transaction elements, Bitcoin-script changes, and is in Bitcoin Classic beta, pending deployment strategy.

today_in_history_posts.title: Testing a Flare-like routing implementation on 2500 AWS nodes
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Flare is a modified routing protocol tested in Eclair for the Lightning Network.
- Implementation focuses on encrypted inter-node communication through open channels.
- Tests indicate high route discovery success, barring directional graph complexities and bug issues.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The `utxozkp` tool enhances Lightning Network privacy by proving UTXO set inclusion in zero knowledge.
- Current limitations include inability to prevent a UTXO's multiple proof uses; future updates will expand its functions.
- Performance evaluations on an Apple M1 Max showed a 6-minute proof generation time and 1.4 MB proof size.
